message: I always see "x" programming language is faster than "y" programming language. Is the difference really worth switching or really noticeable like 5 minutes faster?

data.message: There is no need to switch, Depend on the requirement of the project you work on you can choose the best suited language(s) and tools.

5 minutes means ages in computer time
I guess the differences are noticeable in really big systems so it depend on your projects
I am still a learner but i read in many places that every language is good and fast at somethings and bad at others so the language you choose should depend on the project itself
And yes i saw a case where the programming language made a difference greater than 5 min. something database related and was solved by converting to Asp .net

آه طبعا!
متقدرش تكتب حاجة زي نظام التشغيل بالبايثون. و اللغة الابطأ يعني عادة بتستخدم أبنية معلومات أكبر
Also, in this era, a response time  over a second for your web service can literally put you out of business. 5 minutes is not even an option.

الناس لما تكون بتعمل حاجة realtime بتكون مضايقة من الكام millisecond pause بتوع الgarbage collection مثلا فا ممكن يروحوا للغة تانية مش garbage collected. مثلا Go في اخر version قللوا الpause من 10 millisecond ل 100 microsecond و كان إنجاز و على Homepage HN و بتاع. فا اه هي بتعتمد بشكل كبير على أنت عايز تعمل ايه.
Not in Egypt but brokerages worry about milliseconds in code to get that trade
It is 5 minutes faster on your minimal expirement, imagine how fast it'll be on large-scale usecase.

it depends on the application, like network programming that doesn't do much computation most of the time is spent in the network delay whatever language you are using, numerical and scientific computing that depends on complex algorithms you need a fast language (that's why numpy in python is actually written in c++), also that's why there is the FFI (foreign function interface) in most languages, so you can reuse fast algorithms implementated in different languages into your code without having to rewrite or learn too much about the other languages
